1. Cedarbaum JM, Stambler N, Malta E, Fuller C, Hilt D, Thurmond B, Nakanishi A. The ALSFRS-R: a revised ALS functional rating scale that incorporates assessments of respiratory function. BDNF ALS Study Group (Phase III). J Neurol Sci. 1999 Oct 31;169(1-2):13-21. doi: 10.1016/s0022-510x(99)00210-5. PMID: 10540002. 2. Kaufmann P, Levy G, Thompson JL, Delbene ML, Battista V, Gordon PH, Rowland LP, Levin B, Mitsumoto H. The ALSFRSr predicts survival time in an ALS clinic population. Neurology. 2005 Jan 11;64(1):38-43. doi: 10.1212/01.WNL.0000148648.38313.64. PMID: 15642901. 3. Kimura F, Fujimura C, Ishida S, Nakajima H, Furutama D, Uehara H, Shinoda K, Sugino M, Hanafusa T. Progression rate of ALSFRS-R at time of diagnosis predicts survival time in ALS. Neurology. 2006 Jan 24;66(2):265-7. doi: 10.1212/01.wnl.0000194316.91908.8a. PMID: 16434671. 4. Cedarbaum JM, Stambler N. Performance of the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Functional Rating Scale (ALSFRS) in multicenter clinical trials. J Neurol Sci. 1997 Oct;152 Suppl 1:S1-9. doi: 10.1016/s0022-510x(97)00237-2. PMID: 9419047.

details.purpose: To record the results for each component parameter and the ALSFRS-R score.
details.use: Use to record the results for each component parameter and the ALSFRS-R score.

items.items: Revised Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Functional Rating Scale (ALSFRS-R)
An assessment score used to stratify severity of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), including respiratory function.
Marked drooling; requires constant tissue or handkerchief
Marked excess of saliva with some drooling
Moderately excessive saliva; may have minimal drooling
Slight but definite excess of saliva in mouth; may have nighttime drooling
Nothing by mouth; exclusively parenteral or enteral feeding
Able to grip pen but unable to write
Slow or sloppy; all words are legible
Patients with gastrostomy and >50% daily nutrition intake via G-tube
Cutting food and handling utensils (patients with gastrostomy)
Unable to perform any aspect of task
Some help needed with closures and fasteners
Clumsy but able to perform all manipulations independently
Independent and complete self-care with effort or decreased efficiency
Turning in bed and adjusting bed clothes
Can initiate but not turn or adjust sheets alone
Can turn alone or adjust sheets but with great difficulty
Somewhat slow and clumsy but no help needed
Significant difficulty, considering using mechanical respiratory support
Occurs at rest, difficulty breathing when either sitting or lying
Occurs with one or more of the following eating, bathing, dressing
Needs extra pillows in order to sleep (>2)
Some difficulty sleeping at night due to shortness of breath; does not routinely use >2 pillows
Invasive mechanical ventilation by intubation or tracheostomy
Continuous use of BiPAP during the night and day
Continuous use of BiPAP during the night
Cutting food and handling utensils (patients without gastrostomy)
Food must be cut by someone but can still feed slowly
Can cut most foods although clumsy and slow; some help needed
Somewhat slow and clumsy but no help needed
